title: Network epistemology in practice
descriptions:
Here is a potential abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Network Epistemology in Practice: Understanding Collective Knowledge Generation at CERN

This project proposes to investigate the epistemology of large-scale scientific collaborations, focusing on particle physics at the European Center for Nuclear Research (CERN). By analyzing internal communication documents, including emails and wiki pages, we aim to understand how knowledge is generated and validated in these complex research environments. Our objectives include characterizing collective research processes, reconstructing internal communication networks, and developing historiographic guidelines for future studies. We will adapt theoretical models of network epistemology to inform our analysis and contribute to the philosophy of collective knowledge generation. Methodologically, we will innovate by applying digital tools and computational methods to the study of born-digital sources. The project's outcomes will include practical strategies for best practices in history and philosophy of science, as well as historiographic guidelines for studies based on born-digital sources. By shedding light on the epistemology of large-scale scientific collaborations, this project will address a critical challenge in the history and philosophy of science, with implications for our understanding of collective knowledge generation and validation.

This project explores the epistemology of large-scale scientific collaborations, focusing on particle physics at the European Center for Nuclear Research (CERN). By analyzing internal communication documents, including emails and wiki pages, we aim to understand how knowledge is generated and validated in these complex research environments. Our objectives include characterizing collective research processes, reconstructing internal communication networks, developing historiographic guidelines for future studies, and contributing to the philosophy of collective knowledge generation. We will adapt theoretical models of network epistemology to the case study of CERN, innovatively applying digital tools and computational methods to address the challenge of capturing large-scale, complex research processes for epistemological analysis. The project's expected contributions include historiographic guidelines for studies based on born-digital sources and practical strategies for best practices in history and philosophy of science. By shedding light on the epistemological underpinnings of scientific collaboration, this project will provide valuable insights into the nature of collective knowledge generation in modern science.

This project proposes to investigate the epistemology of large-scale scientific collaborations, focusing on the European Center for Nuclear Research (CERN) as a case study. By addressing the challenge of capturing large-scale, complex research processes for epistemological analysis, this project will advance our understanding of how scientific knowledge is created and validated in the 21st century.
